context: You also used different parts from the assage for each paragraph where as I've noticed it common to use similar instances form the passage through out an essay.
good use of language, though a few gramatical errors.

Specific and direct references to the text which showcased the rhetorical strategies used by the author that were mentioned in the thesis. May want to reword the idea that the author used official statistics which was not shown in the originl document. Appeal to logos more appropriate
You had great explainations for your evidence.

great organization!  The three body paragraphs were really good and interesting and each one was well structured and good job avoiding being repetitive.  The structure of your essay is well organized and covers everything you talked about in your thesis.
Good vocabulary and correct grammar, save for one or two small errors in punctuation.

Make sure though that all of your evidence directly supports your argument. For example, the statement about the parents contradictions supports that kids are less appreciative of nature, but it does not support that parents/the older generation was any better. If they are encouraging kids to indulge in electronics, then these parents are just as unappreciative of nature as the kids. You can fix this problem either by broadening your thesis statement or by using part of that evidence as an example.
Great job expalining the evidence that you used.
The thesis is solid because it ties Louv's position in with the three devices the author plans to discuss in the rest of the essay.
Your agrument is very well written and you do a good job expaling each piece of evidence and analyzing each quote. I would go back and try and make your quotes fit in your pasages better.
the thesis is clear and lists important devices used in the speech.

Although the thesis addresses the fact that Kelley uses rhetorical strategies to ''strengthen her speech and create a message,'' it does not adress specifically what strategies she used to convey this message.  It would have been a stronger thesis if they had taken the topics of their body paragraphs and plugged those in as the particular strategies used.  Also, in the lead up to the thesis there is a lot of background information about the author of the prompt and her background instead of leading into the actual thesis.  In relation to the preceding sentences the thesis seems unconnected.  I would reccomend weaving the thesis tighter into the introduction.
The author uses three obvious rhetorical strategies that Kelley used throughout her speech. However they do not include more sophisticated techniques such as evoking nostalgia.

The author clearly used a precis format to formulate their introductory paragraph, however their thesis was not very clear, if any. Although using a precis format was very simple and easy to gather all the ideas into one centralized paragraph, it was jumbled and confusing. It did not seem to flow and I had a hard time even deciding what the thesis could have been. The author should have done one straightfoward thesis at the end of the paragraph that included the rehtorical strategies and how the author uses them to convey his point. Instead, they decided to separate the two making it seem as if they were working backwards.

Your language, although not completely perfect, is generally very well written. It shows you to have a good control of your writing and that you have a mature style and thinking. There are some mistakes though, such as that strange part in the first paragraph where the grammar is mixed up and you are excessively making separate sentences of the girls working in different conditions which I feel could be compressed down to one or two sentences, which would better your essay and make the language make much more sense. There are also other places with mistakes where I feel commas were due and where words that should've been plural were not. There were some words left out in places that made the sentences sound slightly off and some words/wording that didn't work and should've been done differently. Although it's not essay breaking, it breaks apart that mature writing that you show throughout the rest of the essay and I would recommend going over your essay again and check for grammatical and spelling errors.

In terms of the author's specific thesis though, the commentary is sufficient in supporting the idea that there is a separation between people and nature.  It needs to be expanded though if it wishes to address the prompt completely.
Always stays in the third person, it's good that it doesn't jump around.

I know there were strict time constraints on this essay and it was tough to finish. Good job on getting a beginning, middle, and end. However, the conclusion should have at least three sentences, starting with a restatement of th thesis which was done and then going to broader ideas, ending with a universal claim.
This thesis covers the basis of the text and is very well supported by the rest of the essay.

Throughout your essay you used many quotes from the piece which did help support your paper in a positive way. There were many examples, however, of you using ''naked'' quotes. You simply put a quote into your writing without any connection to the rest of the piece other than ''Louv says''. If you imbed the quotes more smoothly into your writing, this paper would be greatly improved.
In your introduction you could maybe consider adding some more background information such as Kelley's opinions on child labors laws and the efforts she was taking in order to make a change.
Made good connections to the real life and how technology could be affecting us.
You thoroughly explained the evidence that you cited.  However you could have specified where Kelley applied the techniques that you said she used.
Despite not being in all places, all evidence presented is explained in a concise fashion, getting the point across with no strings attached.
With evidence, you also state your own based-on-knowledge infromation regarding the text. A few more examples with citations (2+ evidence) for each rhetorical strategy would make it even stronger.

I think that you mislabeled the guilt that you wrote about in your first body paragraph. Guilt should be a big part of the paragraph, but the topic should be about Kelley's appeal to pathos (sentimental appeal, emotions of the reader, etc). Besides that, the first body paragraph talks about relevant information in the speech and it gives a decent description of how Kelley guilts the readers.
Language is sufficient but could be expanded upon.
Be specific as to what technological innovation you are referring to.
Organization is very clear. No troubles in understanding the logical flow of ideas in your essay.

You did not explain his agruement at all through your entire paper, all you did was state that there was a seperation. You did not explain his agruement just that nature was good. You need to explain his agruement about the seperation and how and why there is a sepration.
its clear you use some strategies but you could have pcked a few more maybe
Your thesis is good but the author's name is Louv not Price.

The author did a good job on analyzing Louvs strategies to help support their argument.  This is because they took a quote from the text and explained it and related their explanation back to the text.

The thrid paragraph contains a lot of good evidence, but the sheer amount of evidence provided detracts from the essay as a whole as the essay tends to lack crucial analysis to justify claims and seems to be almost a list of techniques rather than a rhetorical analysis. Cutting down on some of the evidence stated in exchange for more analysis would strengthen the paragraph. For example, rather than talking about the nostalgic tone, anaphora, and satirical tone towards the end of the third paragraph one could focus on the effect of the anaphora, which is mentioned in the thesis, and not confuse the audience by flooding them with different types of techniques like tone.

Your analysis of the rheetorical strategies used shows that you have a clear understanding of Kelley's reasoning for her speech. In the second paragraph, it is not clear which rehtorical strategy you are writing of until the 5th sentence, which is a bit confusing for the reader. It is a bit unclear throughout the essay which strategies you are describing as you do not explicitly state which ones you are analyzing. However, the reader is able to understand this by reading your analysis of evidence.

You don't really have all that many quotes in your essay to support your points that you are trying to argue. In the first body paragraph you have a quote, but in both the second and third ones, you either use light paraphrasing or you don't use a quote at all. I think that quotes are a necessary piece of evidence that you need to encorporate into your essay in order to get a strong grade. In the second body paragraph I think that you could add a quote about one of the different legistations (Georgia, one of the Carolinas) because it shows how knowledgable Kelley is on the topic of child labor. In the third body, use a quote that has the word we instead of just saying ''we'' all the time because the readers need to see an example of her technique being used in the speech.

This essay is wel written, but it is choppy at some points. Sentances don't flow together as well as they could. However, I saw litle to no grammatical errors, vocabulary was also pretty well chosen. The writing doesn't divert from the argument either.
The author uses very sophisticated language in the essay. The author does not includes words such as ''illustrates'' and employs instead of ''uses.'' This conveys the author's arguments bettter.

The introduction and conclusion mirrored each other. Something that may help, would be to add a new thought or idea that was not previously mentioned in order to keep the audience thinking and contemplating throughout the whole essay all the way to the end.
The authors diction was basic and not well developed. They used general words and phrases not a lot of vocabulary. It was good how the author mentioned realism.
You lost a point for the language paragraph because you did not use as much evidence and did not go as in depth as the others.
Your essay is more of a summary rather than an analysis mixed in with personal analogies and ideas of the prompt.  You should address the prompt more often.

I think you did a fairly great job in explaining his argument, ''All in all Louv argues that humans are drifting further apart form nature due to the advancement of technology. His rhetorical questions emphasize that humans are the sole reason for the separation'' was worded nicely and clearly.
This essay is freaking awesome. Like i have nothing to say.
'but yet'' is redundant; they both mean the same thing.
It would be best to keep the thesis in one sentence. Also, you need a hook or and intro to lead into your thesis rather than just having your thesis as the only thing in your intro.

You provided no textual evidence for your claim that Louv uses the appeal to pathos in his argument. This can be found in body paragraph three of your essay. Consider incorporating this textual evidence, ''We used our fingers to draw pictures on fogged glass as we watched telephone poles tick by. We considered the past and dreamed of the future, and watched it all go by in the blink of an eye.'' Then explain your own personal thoughts on this evidence and how the use of pathos directly affected you.
There is a suffice amount of specific textual evidence in each body paragraph. All the evidence used supported the argument well. Suffice amount of direct quotes which also made the essay strong.

The language seemed a little bit forced with some awkwardly placed words. Rather than using ''exacerbated,'' try using aggravate or irritate, as it flows easier and doesn't seem as forced. As for the essay as a whole, your vocab is adequate, and there are minimal grammar mistakes. Although, and this is very important, you have to remember to cite which part of Louv's work you got the quotes from. You only place quotes, but do not cite them or give any indication that it comes from a certain page in Louv's work.

The author discusses Louv's ''equipment of an anecdote, imagery, and rhetorical questioning,'' to support Louv's arguement. Though the analysis of the rhetorical strategies were very minimal, it was clear they understood the message and Louv's purpose. The evidence of an anecdote portrayed society's growing seperation but most of the paragrapg was summary with just an ending sentence providing analysis. Within the paragraph discussing rhetorical strategies, it seems the author making great inferences and doesnt seem to connect it back to the thesis and purpose.
The author is able to speak in an educated manner, rarely deviating from the constant didactic manner.
colorful use of language in some places and others not as much but pretty consistent throughout

First, you mentioned the author as ''Richard''. NEVER EVER!! You cannot say his first name, its just forbidden. You must address him as Louv. In the second paragraph, you say ''Louv portay.'' It must be **Portrays. You have some typo's in here.. reread your work. You wrote ''live'' instead of ''like.''    In this sentence, ''Louv further supported his argument by including his friend’s reasoning as to why they did not want a backseat television'' It should be ''it'' not ''they'' becuase its ONE friend, not multiple people.

The overall organization in the essay is great. All of your body paragraphs follow the generalization that is introduced in your thesis statement. They follow a logical order that effectively develops your evidence and argument. Although, your thesis has room for improvement. Instead of stating a gerneralization about technology, it would be more effective to introduce a list that is more specific to each of your body paragraphs. This would make your essay more logical and easier to comprehend.
had good strategies used but need to explain why and how they were effective especially second paragraph

Your thesis set-up created a good direction for your essay which allowed you to flow from one topic to the next.   Seperate your first body paragraph into two body paragraphs.  In your thesis sepereate the appeal to pathos and logos as different strategies. I know due to time constraints it was difficult to finish the essay.  For the newly formed first body paragraph use ''while the we sleep''  and you can talk about how she incorporates the birthday parties to appeal to pathos and for you second  body paragraph you can say she appeals to logos because she makes it clear that the children are creating clothing for the adults so the adults should be making it.  You can also use how she point out that there are no restrictions to add to the logos.  Your original second body paragraph diverges from the topic you set up in your topic sentence.  You are talking about the solution but then go on about slippery slope.  And although slippery slope is a rhetorical strategy, providing a solution isn't.  You might want to take that part out all together.  You can just talk about logos and pathos, but I would recomend having three body paragraphs.

You didn't use any direct quotes to help support your claims, excpet for the very first quote you used and I'm not sure how you related that in. Use more direct quotes from Louv's [assage to help you support what your claims are.

The author provides a detailed explanation of evidence for the quotes that he/she used. The second paragraph is in my opinion the strongest in the essay, and the evidence pulled for that paragraph was well explained. It conveyed the writiers thoughts very clearly. Sometimes phrasing was difficult or a word was omitted by accident, or the author was writing about something that was not in the thesis, but it did not lack clarity of explanation and analysis of quotes.

The thesis clearly states the rhetorical techniques the author will be analyzing, but fails to state the actual effect of technology on humans. This absense results in the thesis not directly responding to the prompt, leaving the rest of the essay discovering itself as it progresses. While the thesis provides a general format for the rest of the essay and promises to discuss the rhetorical strategies to the reader, it does not relate these strategies back to the prompt adequately.

Grammatical errors are fairly common in this essay. ''Therefore, children being continuously separated from the Earth that supports life and provides imagination and dreams of the future.'' should have been ''Therfore, children are being continuously separated from the Earth which supports life and provides imagination and dreams of the future.'' Errors in sentance structure such as this is too prevelent in this essay indicating that the author should take more time to review their work before submitting it.
You did a really good job analyzing the passage and making connections to the rhetorical devices, however I feel like you should have gave more of what you think after every connection.
Organization was perfect, the only thing I would suggest is to combine your first two sentences in some way instead of keeping them seperate.
(1) For every claim you had, there was a thorough explainataion that followed. There were always connections that flowed nicely and you never failed to tie it all back to your original thesis.
Very sophisticated vocabulary, and well tuned to the assignment. No need for improvement here.

The use of the rhetorical techniques of: point of view of audience, anaphora, and epistrophe are very well used and have more than 1 quote to back up the rhetorical device. Good introduction to arrive into the rhetorical device, not to just state the rhetorical device and then explain why with evidence.
thye explained it well by referncing the text with the points.

The author analyzed the rhetorical strategies very well. The thesis itself does not list specific tools or names though. But when you read the whole rhetorical analysis, it is clear how the author used certain language manipulation to appeal to ethos and pathos. The first rhetorical device is harder to understand than the other two but it is probably the most powerful device, and it was clear after reading the analysis.

I love that after reading this I gained new insight on the possible rhetorical strategies used, I didn't think of the reversed societal roles but that's a good point! Again on the logical reasoning bit, try to go further into it: ''Kelley uses a straightforward and accurate presentation of the facts at hand to maintain the initial trust the NAWSA placed in her. This trust keeps the audience interested in the campaign without feeling that they're being told an exaggerated story.'' or something :)

At the end of your thesis in paragraph 1, you did not restate what the reader should agree to. It would be better to remind the audience what argument Louv is stating. What does Louv persuade the audience to agree to? To improve the thesis you can restate the argument.

It would be a well organized essay paragraph-wise, but make sure you include everything you should for each body paragraphs. Both paragraphs have very different strengths, but you may have run out of time for the second?
The author should have used more detail and been a little more clear.

Your thesis was not very complex and it's generally better not to directly use the words ''pathos'' and ''logos.'' Also try to to rephrase your thesis so that it includes if the rehtorical strategies used are effective or not, or why they work.

The following body paragraphs, are explained very well when standing alone. On the other hand, the paragraphs go hand in hand. When the author states, ''Then the essay takes a turn...'' it really isn't taking a turn. I, as a reader, am confused on the big difference between the arguments the writer is suggesting. The statements that the author makes ''advertizing industry has gotten out of control'' and that ''we are disconnected from the nature outside'' really go hand in hand. The statements both believe that people aren't valuing nature. So overall, a little unclear.

The strategies of pathos, repetition, and sarcasm were well used and analyzed. Repetition is a good strategy to open with becuase it automatically connects to the essay and we can see more about the emphasis the author wished to apply, whether than his perspective and then just moving on.

Your thesis claims that Louv's argument is that nature is important to today's youth, but one of the main points of the essay is to show how the importance of nature in society is declining. It's the opposite of what you are saying. Maybe you could say something like, ''Throughout the passage the writer uses rhetorical devices such as ethos and pathos to show the audience that children need to pay more attention to nature.''

The organization is set up really well in the essay. Each section has a clear direction and uses specific rhetorical devices set up in the introdution and thesis statement. It is very clear what you will be talking about next. The only issue is that as a reader we were waiting to hear about sarcasm but it never came into play.

Organization was adequate, thesis provided a very basic outline of what was going to be spoken on in the essay. Thesis should be in order of the body paragraphs. The author switches the order of the two body paragraphs from the thesis to the body paragraphs.  Body paragraphs loosely relate to the thesis, should be a much clearer relation. This could be solved by having a clearer thesis, and topic sentences based on the thesis at the beginning of every body paragraph.

Your word choice was very unacademic, like saying ''word choice'' instead of ''diction.'' Replacing words like ''use'' and ''show'' with stronger verbs will make you a stronger writer. You have many spelling errors that make it difficult to understand and some of your sentences don't make sense. Ex. ''The repetition in the last paragraph of Louv’s argument creates a feeling of recognition and realization in the passage now. '' Once you finish writing your paper you should go through and edit your paper for these illogical sentences and edit spelling mistakes.
For what rhetorical devices are presented they have some claim.

The author describes the textual evidence he or she uses to a certain extent.  The author describes the textual evidence quite vaguely in only about a sentence. For example he or she states, ''When she lays so much guilt down, she tries to make sure it is equal for everyone in her audience...''  It would be better to go indepth on the guilt and how it is ''equal foreveryone.''

Strong thesis, but using specific rhetorical devices (not just saying 'rhetorical devices') will make the purpose of the essay more clear. Indicate what the purpose of this 'persuasive and educational' speech is. It is implied but I feel as if it will specify your thesis more.

First of all, for the introduction, work more to integrate the background, SOAPSTONE, and other essential information so that the paragraph flows and everything is succint. While the thesis makes an attempt to list rhetorical srategies, it seems to stand alone in the paragraph. With the information provided on Florence Kelley in the promt, it is clear that she is a committed social worker and would chose to write passionately on this matter. With that said, focus more on the actual strategies and goals of the author, and not merely list ethos and logos. Please also delete ''solid rhetorical strategies''.

In your essay, you utilize a sophisticated vocabulary. I think that the quality of your essay could drastically improve if you were to go back through and clean up the repition of words as well as dull helping and linking verbs. Additionally, your sentence structure at times is plain and could be given more life. For example, your analysis seems to always state ''Kelley directly...'' but you don't elaborate on these points as much as you can. Always try to take a quick run through of your writing after you are done so that you can check quick grammar or spelling errors which take the sophistication out of your writing. Ex. (she directly address her audience) [change address to ''addresses'']
The evidence that you did provide was well analyzed and thought out. The only change I would consider making is ending your third body paragraph with analysis.
The thesis acknowledges that Louv uses rhetorical strategies but does not say what the strategies were.
the thesis statement is not strong. needs reasoning for why. the three reasons talked about in the paragraphs

The essay has a distinct introduction and conclusion both of which connect Louv's passage to a more global statement. However, the body paragraph should be broken up into multiple paragraphs based on the strategy/quote being analyzed and each quote requires a more thorough explanation and connection back to the thesis and the author's purpose. When it is stated that ''he first demonstrates the disconnection...'', the reader is expecting there to be a ''he then demonstrates...'' following afterwards with a different point. However, that line is followed by a change in topic as you switch to a different quote to discuss. The transitions are basic, and some of the connections are not immediately obvious to the reader.

You identified enough rhetorical stratagies, and explained them, but I feel as if your explanations could have been more thorough and connected more to Louv's argument. There is typically only one sentence at the end of each paragraph that really connects what the device is used to accomplish and how it accomplishes this in Louv's essay.
The organization is alright.  The paragraphs do seem jumbled and could be condensed to focus on one rhetorical device, and then its analysis.

You did a really good job of not only providing details about how the Kelley's techniques swayed the audience as a whole, but you also continued in describing how Kelley's rhetorical strategies affected the individual audience member's emotions. I would suggest you continue with explaining textual evidence by descibing its effects as a whole and for the individual listener.
Decent thesis could be more specific but no major issues.
In the third paragraph, you begin with making mention to a general part of the passage. Instead of just vaguley describing this situation, pull out direct quotes from that section.
After each explanation, this student would go into more detail about it to make sure the reader fully understood what they were trying to say.

The overall control of language and conventions in this essay is satisfactory. Despite one or two run on sentences the grammar was great and the vocabulary was adequate. There is always room for improvement in the diction category so always strive to choose the best words possible, but great job on word choice in this essay.

This was the best part of the essay to me because you really took time to explain the reasons you felt Louv was doing things using rhetorical devices. There was lots of arguments for your evidence and i think it just gives off the impression that its your real opinion.

Your statement that Louv's argument is that nature is important to today's youth is not completely correct. His argument is meant to point out that the gap between humans and nature is growing, and swallowing up children's awareness of the world around them in the process. Think a bit more about it before revising.

The author includes adequate amount of evidence for his or her analysis of Louv's rhetorical stragies. However, the references and ideas taken from the text don't necessarily connect back to the thesis. Sometimes it is hard to tell whether the evidence supports the idea of growing separation of nature and people or how people must ''patch up separation between people and nature.''

There are some areas of potential improvement for this thesis. The thesis is a run-on sentence as ''and'' is used twice. Furthermore ''laments'' is a very strong word and does not reflect Louv's feelings towards the situation; although he finds a loss of appreciation for nature, he does not hate the current generation.

The overall organization of the essay is done well, but the progression of ideas does not have the same effect. Having four pragraphs, the conclusion doesn't include all or anything of what the writer has tried to explain through use of tense change and anecdotes, and is very nare bones and two sentences long. The greatest amount of progression came in the second body paragraph, but if it was made the first pargraph the essay may have had more clarity and flow.

You explain the Rhetorical strategies well that you have chosen, however, to take your essay to the next level I would suggest talking about harder less obvious rhetorical strategies. I also think you can incorperate how Louv uses the rhetoric strategies to make his argument stronger a little better. You have great evidence for your quotes you just need to explain your stratiges better.
A few grammatical errors here and there, but nothing too major.

In the second paragraph you have quotes to support you TS, but in the second you only have one quote and in one part you reference the passage but if a quote was used it would add more credibility to your essay.
good but try making the thesis one sentence

Overall the author did well in explaining the evidence, however when discussing metaphors there was one example of where the explanation could be better. There is never a clear explanation of the importance or relevance of “using nature as ad space”.
Well since there wasn't much textual evidence, there wasn't much to explain. But what was explained was okay.

Some of your sentences are awkward because they are either run-on sentences or written in passive voice. In your introductory paragraph, you say, '' Louv argues that an overlap of nature and technology is unacceptable , that bringing advanced technology into many areas of our life is not at all appropriate and would lead to nature and culture having little value.'' This sentence is a run- on sentence and confuses the reader. To make your sentences stronger, either divide them into two sentences or have them written in active voice.
Many advanced rhetorical strategies were analyzed and explained very thoroughly.

You left out a lot of details about the parts of Louv's passage, such as the anecdote of his friend, Instead, you take out pieces from all over the paper, which make it difficult to see exactly what you are reffering to in your analysis.
mostly simple language with few exception. overuse of ''demonstrates'' or ''demonstrating''
each paragraph focused on that particular argument and was extremely organized and you fully supported each of your strats.

I didnt see much of a theis statment in the essay. What would be better for the theis to deelope the rest of your essay is to list the rhetorical strategies your analyzing. Your explanation of repetition was understandable, despite its length. However, the explanations for Kelley's appeal to pathos and her use of rhetorical questions were lacking. Your analyses that come from your exploration of rhetorical strategies, to me, seem to not go deep enough. Yes, Louv is saying that the separation is bad. He makes that quite clear. I would have liked to see a more in-depth analysis of what the rhetorical strategies do for that argument, how they actually add more to it rather than them just be something Louv uses to further get across his point.
By using the thesis as the very first sentence it grabs the readers attention but it could also turn readers away if they are not interested.

The tone thorughout your paper often switches from past tense to present tense, which avoids having a constant voice. Usually with writing, we use present tense when discussing the authour because when reading their work, their writing comes to life. :)
This explanation was very clear and precise.  Everyexplanation was right on point and they followed along with Louv's argument.

Very nice thesis but you meant ''inhumane'' instead of ''humane''. Its also a little unclear about what you mean when you say ''personal'' diction you should switch it to say ''personal pronouns''. Overall a really good thesis.
The argument should be included in the thesis statement rather than in a separate sentence.

Your introduction is very basic. But your thesis is clear and concise. You tell the reader the rhetorical stratagies that Louv implements as well as those that you're going to review. When you say ''in order to illustrate his opinion of the overcoming problem...'' you tell exactly what you're going to be proving throughout your essay. That asserts to the reader what they're in for.

Opening sentence of first body paragraph looks as if it is going to support the argument, however the rest of the paragraph is off topic and ventures far from the argument itself. Focus more on what Louv is arguning, instead of why he is a credilble source for the argument.

Your control of language is good but could be much better. The near-constant use of to be + verb (is making, is used, is also using, is saying) makes your writing less sophisticated. The first sentence in the third paragraph has grammatical errors.
Logos. Pathos. Ethos. The basic three for all arguements. Use them. They will also help you get your point across more concisely.

The language used was great and you were able to create a certain tone throughout the piece. Your use of high level vocab and unique adjectives made the essay more enjoyable to read and made the whole essay more sophisticated.

When you write, ''There she addressed the terrible working conditions that girls had undergone across the nation...with repetition of key phrases, inclusive diction, and exclamatory and interrogative syntax. Kelly heavily relies on pathos and her knowledge of the audience to persuade them,'' you connected precisely the message Kelley conveys to the devices she uses by first, including her background information (where'd you get this?).

Your explanation of evidence is weak in some areas. When you explained the ''we'' in your first body paragraph that was good. Your second paragraph also provided more analysis than any of your other paragraphs which was good. But in your later paragraphs you made general comments about the evidence but didn't analyze it as much as needed. You have to many quotes and you just explained them or restated them in your own words but it didn't provide any substance to your paper. there was hardly any analysis in the 3rd paragraph. So definitely reduce the amount of quotes and add more analysis.

Again, I don't really think storytelling and contrasting are rhetorical devices. Maybe you could use pathos and diction instead. Plus, I think your use of ''contrasting'' is the same thing as storytelling. Yes, he does contrast the way things were back in the day to how things are now, but that is also a story. Plus, you don't explain how that builds Louv's overall argument.
Referred to the text and supported Louv's rhetorical strategy but didn't use more than one example from the text.

In order to analyze Louv's rhetorical strategies, you mention that the adamant woman allows Louv to assert that ''man needs to be connected through nature and not through materialistic items.'' What did this adamant women do that would lead to this?

The chosen evidence is good but each rhetorical device needs more supporting evidence from the text. Addition of more quotes will strengthen your claim and provide more support for each rhetorical device.

Why you mention repetition in Louv's passage, you didn't provide evidence for this rhetorical device. ''He starts each sentence with “We” to refer to the previous generation and what they did in cars and their connection to nature.'' You mention the two generations that Louv contrasts, but you supply no evidence for their connection to nature.

Fourth par: ''...rapidly as the young firs from...'' I assume ''girls'' goes where ''firs'' is. Small error, easy fix. Fifth par: ''She concludes with a statement that portrays the children as the future of the country, and how important it is that they are treated fairly so they will make good decisions in the future.'' Read this over. You need a verb before ''how important'' and you should get rid of that comma. Edited version: She concludes with a statement that portrays blah blah blah... and [insert verb...explains? asserts? idk] how blah blah blah.'' But I also suggest taking out the ''statement'' altogether, and maybe trying ''She concludes with a portrayal of children as the future of the country and an [insert noun lol...explanation? assertion? idk just ideas] of how important...'' The ''statement'' thing is unnecessary and obstructs the flow of your sentence.

The author adequately explains Louv’s argument about the separation between people and nature throughout the entire essay. He employs implicit and explicit evidence integrated throughout his essay to bolster Louv’s purpose. He provides commentary such as “children of the new generation who he believes will lose all notice of the real world while being sucked into the virtual one” and “he helps to portray the widespread of children addicted to technology” both of which highlight the purpose but provide further insight and analysis. He also effectively analyzed Louv’s strategies and how they reinforce Louv’s essay stating how Louv creates pathos through nostalgia and employs diction such as “we” to imply separation of generations are both accurate assertions and make sense. his advance vocabulary also helps to convey a more descriptive meaning and portrays  intelligence and advanced writing.

In paragraph 3, you discuss the following idea: ''In the context of the sentence, Louv identifies another fault of human beings– the desire for perfection. Perfection in nature is within the eyes of the beholder. A landscape may not appear “picture-perfect,” but something worth appreciating is always present.'' While this is part of Louv's point, it is not clearly identified as a rhetorical strategy, thus making the example unclear. To fix this, add a sentence about which rhetorical strategy is displayed.
The author uses a mature tone throughout the essay, and uses specific academic terminology (ethos, pathos, repetition, anaphora).

Try to incorporate a better hook for the reader, maybe an analogy or some simile tying nature and people into a bigger more abstract picture. Just to spice up the intro and make it less bland and robotic.

your vocabulary i thought was pretty good you didnt try to over do it and use words out of context

In the second body paragraph, the notion that Richtel's argument serves as a juxtaposition to Louv's ideas is interesting; but once again, the writer just does not have enough words to develop the idea so that he/she can make the contrast become especially apparent.  Also, the juxtaposition is not entirely correct, as the writer compares Richtel's belief that advertisements ''need to be further spread throughout the social conscious of the nation'' to Louv's argument that ''nature is being destroyed''; advertisments and the destruction of nature are not entirely connected to each other.  However, if the author were to mention something about the possiblities of exploiting nature for personal gain as part of what Richtel is insinuating, and then juxtapose this view against Louv's respectful perspective of nature, this paragraph would make more sense.

Good job including lots of analysis. I'm not saying you are guilty of this, but be careful not to use quotes as a substitute for analysis. You always want to put textual evidence into your own words. You have so much evidence (which is a good thing) that it can be a slippery slope: instead of connecting evidence you have just offered to the author's purpose, you can just use more evidence again. This is just restating what the reader already knows (the reader has read the prompt) instead of offering new insight into the passage.

You used some evidence to support your analysis, however, it wasn't enough evidence. For a device you only had one example of it from the text, and with a couple more examples, and thorough explanations of the purpose of the device, it would have been a lot better. But, you did use some evidence. The evidence you used was good and helped support your ideas, you just need a little bit more of it. Also, try not to quote plunk. What I mean by this is don't just put the quote randomly into the sentence, try and make the sentence flow better with the quote. For example, when you said ''in the quote ...'' (2nd body paragraph), it doesn't flow with the sentence. When you put in a quote, you shouldn't say ''in this quote...'', jsut state the quote in a normal sentence. If you do this it will help in terms of making your evidence more clear and easier to understand. All in all, evidence was supportive, just need more of it, and to not quote plunk.

The phrase aims to stir emotion, and to give the audience a reason to work toward change.'' Needs more analysis go more in depth. These statements are already assumed by the reader. '' This rhetorical question serves two purposes to two different audiences. For the women in the audience, it works toward fighting to gain the right to vote. For men, it serves to show that all women are against child labor, and they also should fight against it.'' These statements need to go more in depth, your around the right idea but you need to elaborate more. By appealing to both the voting men and non-voting women separately, Kelley creates a more effective argument for both groups, telling each group what they must do in order to accomplish her goal.'' This is good commentary because it is stating who her main audience is that she is trying to attract. ''Kelleyposes a clever rhetorical  question that simultaneously creates two different effects on different members of the audience  in order to maximize the effectiveness of her speech.'' This doesnt make sense, consider rewording or elaborating on your point. ''This gives an example of how women are able to create change, and shows women in the audience  how they can do their part. By giving them a plan of action, Kelley empowers the non-voting  women of the audience to take action and to indirectly cause the much-needed change in the laws  of child labor.'' This is a broad statement, not much analysis, consider going more into depth and expanding your ideas.

The example, discussed in the first body paragraph, describes the insincere motives humans have for interacting with nature; the anecdote in the second body paragraph explains the expectations of society; and the change in tone discussed in the last body paragraph is adequate to explain the contrast in attitudes towards nature between the past and present.  But the writer, once again, comes up short in mentioning how these devices convey Louv's argument, as the writer focuses on how these devices ''allow Louv to demonstrate the separation of people and nature'' (which does not fully address the prompt). You adequately analyzed Kelley's rhetorical strategies in your first body paragraph by delving deeper into her reasons for use of the word ''we''.  However you could discuss why she includes the ages of the children working and what rhetoical strategy is at work.  Also, to improve your first body paragraph you could include why Kelley imposes guilt on her audience.  In the second body paragraph, you may want to include why she wants to shift the purpose of those paragraphs to those particular states.  What rhetorical strategy is she using?  What is the purpose of staing the lack of restrictions in certain states? Lastly, in the third body paragraph, you may want to include that she appeals to the audience's pathos rather than stating that ''the speech becomes very emotional''.  This would give a clearer view of the rhetorical strategies Kelley chooses to use.

Overall, the organization is good.  However the first strategy you mention in your thesis is your third body paragraph.  It is easier to read when the points that you make in your thesis are in body paragraphs in corresponding order.  So, you may want to consider reorganizing your body paragraphs.  Also, you only lightly touch on the imagery that you mention in your thesis and you skip altogether the informal diction that you originally mentioned.

Organization was provided through the thesis clearly, so the essay was pretty easy to follow. The body paragraphs were generally strong due to your analysis and your conclusion brought everything together nicely. However, they didn't all connect due to very little transitional words/phrases.

The author uses a lot of unnecessary flowery diction that can be very distracting for the reader. For example, when  the author describes the audience as being ''antagonistic'' it is misleading because Kelley does not view the audience that way. The audience of women is Kelley's key to building the child labor reform movement! Excessive lines such as ''shed light on the injustice of child labor'' can appear random because they are unsupported statements that do little to add analysis. The author needs to add reasoning to back up his or her statement about the negative aspects of the work place or else it will leave the reader wondering why the line was put in the essay rather than another line analyzing why Kelley described the extremeties of working conditions and how her description impacts the audience! The words the author uses are eloquent, however, confusing at times when they don't fit in the right context so they should try to be sure that the word used gives the most accurate and clear meaning!

What makes introductions more powerful is how concise they can be without sounding too short or too long. Usually it needs to be excitable and interesting enough to make the reader want to listen to your reasons. The introduction talked about the modern century child labor issues. This may work well with prompts about current child labor issues or human rights. But with Florence Kelley, it may have been a better choice to omit those sentences and talk more about what child labor was portrayed as back then.

I was a little confused on the conclusion sentence. In short I believe the author wanted to conclude that Kelleys strategies caused the audience to feel bad for the children and want to change their reality for the better. I would suggest narrowing down the exotic vocabulary by one or two words to clarify for readers the true meaning of the sentence. Before: ''Kelley’s utilizes woeful hypothetical scenarios to develop empathy from the Philadelphia crowd and deploys compelling stylistic devices to concrete the reality the Child Labor.'' After (example): Kelley utilizes woeful scenarios to develop empathy from the Philidephia crowd and compelling stylisitc devices to relate the harsh reality of child labor and its urgent need to improve.

You told me a little about Louv's argument, however, you didn't fully analyze it. You didn't mention rhetorical strategies, and his whole argument was portrayed through devices, and becasue you didn't analyze rhetorical devices, you cannot fully explain Louv's argument. You did explain a little how he feels towards nature when you mentioned the grandchildren, but you didn't tie it back to rhetorical strategies or the connection between people and nature. When analyzing Louv's argument, you needed to tie it back to the relationship between people and nature and also the devices he uses to convey that relationship. So, you you need to make sure you analyze what the prompt asks you, so you can fully analyze the argument of Louv. But, you did give me an idea of how he feels, so that was good, you just had some trouble getting the whole argument and fully analyzing it.

The essay addresses the strageies in the order of the thesis, and each paragraph connects to the thesis. This can add further development and depth to your arguements, and create a greater sense of togetherness and cohesion.

The thesis is very vague and although it lists the ''strategies'' that Kelley uses in the speech, it does not address how she uses these strategies in her speech, what purpose these strategies serve, and the intended and lasting effect that these strategies create. You may add at the end of the sentence ''....to effectively convey her message about child labor and gather the support of the audience'' for example.  The phrase ''many very clear, precise statements'' is unclear itself. What are these statements? What purpose do they serve? Rather than say ''many very clear, precise statements with an appeal to the ethical issues of child labor'' you can say ''Kelley uses many direct statements that target the ethical issues of child labor.''

Your mentioning of appeals is indeed correct, however you don't necessarily tie these strategies back to the argument. For example, at the end of your second paragraph, you can add ''This generation is slowly drifting away from this as people are now moving towards the aid of a screen for entertainment rather than nature.'' This ties your strategy back to the argument, and following this you can state how or why your emotional appeal makes the argument better.

Your essay is well structures in that the topics of the body paragraohs follows the order in which the thesis presents them.  Within the paragraphs you remain on the topic of the strategy you chose to discuss and provide quotes and analysis for each strategy.  To make your writing flow smoother, revise the topic sentences of each paragraph.  Instead of explicitly stating the strategy that you're going to explain, add some introductory or background information that will smooth the transition between body paragraphs.  Also, try to relate each body paragraph to the one before it so that the essay is cohesive and incorporates all of the rhetorical elements throughout the entire essay.  For example, in body paragraph one, you describe, ''Kelley powerfully asserts a point in her first sentence of her speech by appealing to Logos.'' Rather than staing the purpose of the paragraph so explicitly, embellish the sentence with some more background info.

Your expalnation for your eveidence is one of your strongest points. There are no loose ends and everything you say is supported by your evidence. Your analysis is insightful and ties into your thesis. You really understood both what Kelley was trying to do and how the audience would react.

Your organization is perfect, with the standard introduction, 3 body paragraphs, and short, summarizing conclusion. You seem to have a hybrid of a big idea/chronological essay style, which is very successful for you in this RA essay.  In the chronological essay type, you can delve deeper into the small, but important details of the writing without diverting from the main idea of the body paragraph.  The body paragraphs would switch off where the author alters his/her tone, style, or prose.  I've found success with this method personally, because it is easier to integrate aforementioned rhetorical strategies such as repetition and dark humor.  However, like I said, your method was perfect for this RA essay.

The evidence is mainly direct quotes, but some of them are introduced within the topic sentence. A good structure to use is the PPE format (Point, Proof, Explain), where you make your topic sentences your point, and then bring evidence, explain it, and repeat the proof and explain part until it successfully backs up your point.

The sentence of Louv highlighting many key points should come after you describe his argument between people and nature. In the first paragraph you include a long quote to desribe how Kelley is using ''chilling and poignant'' statistics to convey her message about child labor. That quote is an appeal to pathos. However, you never quite describe this as such. Instead you deem it as ''emotive phrases.''

This essay provides a very strong thesis, which early on enables the reader to understand arguments made later in the paper. For every rhetorical device you used, you found examples from the text and correctly explained them. For example, in this essay you stated, '' Louv later uses humor to better explain his theory. In the body paragraphs, there are not proper transitions. You do not smoothly go from one example to the next. There could be improvement in the organization if in the concluding sentences, you brought the current paragraph into the next one.

''invoking'' ---> ''evoking''  ''sense of sass'' - very colloquial ''Because the public wasn't reacting or responding to the issues about.'' - Try not to start sentences with the word because, also is this a complete thought? great organization!! flows well & easy to follow

The author does not explain Louv's argument about the seperation between people and nature, but instead talks about the gap between generations. “For a century, children’s early understanding of how cities and nature fit together was gained from the backseat.'' This quote was used in the essay and is a great example of a viable quote for Louv's argument of seperation of people and nature. The quote is being contrasted to how children would prefer to “watch Sesame Street or play Grand Theft Auto,” but in the context of the essay, this isn't being contrasted to emphasise the generational gap, but to emphasis how the gap between people and nature has grown. Children now would prefer movies over watching nature, which widens the gap.

You did not explain any of the evidence you provided in the essay. I would reccommend about one to two sentences on analysis after each peice of evidence that should work to prove Louv's argument. Also you are not making an argument, Louv is, so you need to explain and prove what his argument is.
Good uses of language and expression. Not as ''sophisticated'' as could be, but not bad...

Great job with understanding the rhetorical strategies that Kelley used to convey her message. In your first body paragraph, you discuss how using ''we'' is apart of the tone, and while it does effect the tone, using we is using the second person point of view, which is a rhetorical strategy in itself. This is a really quick fix in wording where you can change tone to point of view becuase it allows Kelley's audience to connect with her, but all together great job on this part of the essay!

I definitely liked how u listed the rhetorical devices that Kelley used. One way that I learned that can make a thesis stronger is to assert, structure and control the whole arguement. Orginization is good. There are only 2 body paragraphs although these are dense and detailed another paragraphwould have really completed this essay.

I belieave that the metaphor portion should have been expanded further,

In your second paragraph, the polysyndeton quote supports your point. YOU DON'T SAY ANYTHING ABOUT WOMEN'S SUFFERAGE IN YOUR BODY PARA's. You mention the ''enfranchisement'' of women at the beginning but then you never refer to the lack of female voting power again. That's at least half of her point that you leave out. Discuss this further.

Your essay makes few references to Louv's argument, focusing instead on the purpose of each rhetorical device. When the argument is mentioned, it is not examined in great depth. For example, when you mention the metaphor at the beginning of paragraph 3, you briefly discuss the contrast between generations it illustrates, but you should go further by explaining how it relates to the developmental benefits of watching nature that Louv mentions.

I believe that the first and second strategies, though possible for analysis, contradict each other.  In the first, you say that Louv is an authority, but in the second, you say that he is ''normal.''  Both are applicable, but together, they weaken the overall argument.
The references you used really supported the rhetorical strategies that you mentioned in your thesis.
Instead of the word enfranchisement in the third body, use the word sufferage. I think that word fits well in that sentence.
The thesis should also be two parts. Remember to include what Kelley's thesis is. What is she trying to say in her writing??? and then how do her rhetorical techniques help her prove her thesis?
The author organized the essay very well and brought important explanations into each paragraph.
Lacked a large amount of explanation for evidence, but that which was shown was well written and connected well to the thesis.

The author explains how and why Kelley uses these strategies, also how Kelley uses statistical evidence, pathos, and repetition to gain empathy from the listeners. The selected strategies effective and obvious to Kelley's speech. The author can also add how statistical evidence pertains to logos.
the rhetorical strategies used in the essay need to all be a part of the thesis in the intro. other than that, the rhetorical strategies were effectively explained.

Why would they ask, '''You did what?'''?? If technology is taking over as you say, if ''people actually looked out the window'', why? Why did people look out car windows? You could take textual evidence from the passage and integrate it into your paper.

The control of language was fairly sophisticated however avoid phrases such as ''Louv’s dash of imagery'' because it takes away from the formal tone in your writing. Diction was pretty decent, but it was sometimes excessive.  ''twists and tugs at the strings'' is a phrase that is also pretty cliche, avoid those terms because it takes away from the formality and academic effectiveness in your writing.
Not well. Did not go into detail and gave one sentence for each quote.

Your explanation of the textual evidence was thorough throughout. You made sure there were no naked qutotes and you explained the circumstances behind every quote from the text. Look for a specific example in your first paragraph to strengthen your essay. Good job finding specific examples in your other 2 body paragraphs.

In paragraph one, it begins with ''The first technique that Kelley uses quite effectively is parallel structure. Kelley utilizes parallel sentence structure and phraseology to emphasize her main points to her audience.'' These sentences alone are more than adequate to cover what rhetorical strategies she utilizes in that particular paragraph. The repitition of ''her usage of'' takes away from the main points of the paragraph and the great quotes inserted there.  The audience will know Kelley uses strategies. If they are taken out, the flow of the essay will become smooth and melodious. Try to avoid overusing ''technique'' and ''usages'' because those aren't all there is to them.
The thesis is well written, it includes Lou argument and what rhetorical devices the author uses. There are no problems in the thesis statement so no advice to fix it or revision idea.
I think that this thesis is too forward as a whole and you really shoudl have 3 supporting points.

You didn't have any specif references to the text and I think that was your weakest area.You had your argument set, you said what he did, but you didn't pull quotes from the text to prove your argument.

You have a developed writing style but i think that you could improve your sentence structure and word choice. For example, try to use less helping and linking verbs. Instead, use verbs that evoke a tone you are trying to get through to your reader. Additionally, be assertive with what you say and then use textual evidence to back it up. If you are not sure about something don't say it. For example, even though you don't know who the audience consists of it is best to avoid a wishy washy tone when you state ''the audience is most likely made up of a lot of middle-aged adults''. Try to spend more time expanding your vocabulary and variety of sentence structure.
Your second paragraph has no textual evidence at all. Be sure to always include direct quotes from the passage whenever you're trying to support why Louv uses a certain strategy.

Adding a ''so what'' element to your body paragraphs would elevate your essay. Include that while Louv employed these rhetorical devices to prove his point about the gap between man and nature, why did he want to prove this? By establishing that maybe this piece is a ''call to action'' encouraging others to take a stand to stop this gap from widening, you could add additional examples and commentary proving this point

You seem to have 3 main rhetorical strategies. Knowing this you can minimize the strategies you listed in your thesis to make it more concise. You clearly defined your strategies which was good, there was no confusion to what they were for the reader. Your analysis of them however could use a little improvement. You repeat how the audience agrees with Kelley and how they feel bad. This is true but i think that you can go deeper in your analysis into specifically what in the strategy would make the audience react this way. In paragraph two you provided a little more insight than any of the other paragraphs when you point out the ''twist in thought'' this was insightful. In your 3rd paragraph when you were talking about emotion, you lost focus and changed to talking about logos and ethos instead. If you thought that those were more prevelant to the audiences reaction then you should make your topic sentence about those. There was little to no analysis on pathos. Again, you have great ideas that are all accurate but they just need a little work in the expression.

Your organization was very clear to me. You began with your introduction stating the thesis with three devices. Keeping that in mind you made three body paragraphs (one for each device) which I liked and thought was very logical. And you topped it off with a conclusion in which you restated the thesis.

Like I said before, it would have helped you if you made your thesis more specific, by actually including the names of the rhetorical devices or strategies. However, you make very, very nice connections. The essay is very fluid and I enjoy reading it. I'm enlightened by your connections they are exemplary. Good evidence as well.

The explaination of the evidence you used was done well as well, they discrided what the author was trying to get across in other ways so that the reader might better understand the article they were reading.

The essay is explained well by showing the different types of rhetorical devices that were used and then explaining the original phrase. Both details from the original passage and personal thoughts are used to create a good explaination.

*Just a note: The opening paragraph hooked me in- I love how you incorporated some of your own personal anecdote.* The thesis states both the argument and the three rhetorical devices correctly and succinctly; however, the argument itself does employ a word incorrectly. Your body paragraphs are well mapped out by your introduction and brought back up in the conclusion. The writer is very vague when elaborating on how the textual evidence relays the purpose or device of the passage. Next time try to focus more on being descriptive and getting your ideas down fast enough with the time limit.
Really liked how you explained your idea after every quote and how it effects the audience / why the rhetorical strategy / evidence was effective. I don't think there is anything I can critique.

Instead of referencing ''the polysyndetons from lines 65-77''  you should includee quotes that evince these claims so that the reader can read you essay without having to check the essay to make sure your statement is accurate. Your essay should work as its on entity.
5/7: You explained most of the textual evidence that you provided, however next time make sure that all explanations help to connect your evidence to your thesis.

Never refer to the author by his/her first name. When you first introduce the author, say First Name Last Name, and from then on, refer to the author by last name only. Minor grammar and spelling errors, such as using ''to'' instead of ''too'' or putting commas outside quotations.

You spent a lot of time giving background for the speech in your body paragraph, so it acts more as a summary than analysis.  When you do analyze the quote and her ''urge[ing] us to feel sympathy'' you make a good point.  Try to focus more on analyzing the rhetorical strategies, rather than merely summarizing the passage.  Stay focused on the prompt because your essay is more you arguing with Kelley against child labor than you analyzing how Kelley argued against child labor.

After your quote in your third paragraph, you don't connect it back to neither the strategy  nor the argument at hand. You must state how the evidence you use is important to the development of the argument to get a good score.
The way you organized your essay was very easy to follow!

There was text evidence inside of the explaination, but it was only a little for each rhetorical device. There was a lot of text evidence used to decribe the seperation of nature and people, making the article a strong one.

Your paragraph was organized well because every paragraph had a different rheotical strategy which was used to construct a well-formed essay. Avoid using the phrase in conclusion for a more sophisticated tone. Not very well developed, you mostly relied on your textual evidence to prove your argument, but it is more effective argument if you prove your evidence with logic.

The thesis is too general because you say that Louv uses diction. All this says is that he uses words. You need to add some sort of word that describes what kind of diction he uses. Textual evidence is explained, but sometimes it's just rephrased, such as: ''“the salesman’s jaw dropped when I said I didn’t want a backseat television monitor for the daughter”. It shows how rare it is for a parent to want their child to enjoy nature and not get sucked into technology.'' This isn't too frequent, but is still something you would want to look out for.
The essay was very well organized and done the way we have learned from the beginning of the year. A body paragraph was dedicated to each rhetorical device that connects back to the original thesis.

Repetition wasn't the right strategy to emphasize. I know what you were trying to say but imagery wouldv'e been better. You had so little evidence that it made it difficult for you to come up with a good amount of explanation.
Your thesis is a clear and specific statement that brings in an argument that correlates with Louv's rhetorical strategies about the separation between people and nature.

Consistently you connected your examples back to your thesis and Louv's argument. You clearly understood the passage very well and it is because of this that your essay was effective. By restating Louv's purpose consistently, you made this a strong piece.

You used enough textual evidence, but some of your claims were not backed up. ''He further proves his argument by including evidence from outside sources.'' What outside sources? You need to rearrange the paragraph so the story comes right after this statement.

'This strategy for persuasion seems powerful due to her irate tone which gradually builds'' as do your concluding sentences of body paragraph, showing strong rhetoric uses yourself as well as a strong hold on structure of the essay. good on you

'Furthermore, Kelley compares the children to “beasts of burden” in an effort to provide the audience with appalling imagery that will move them into action.'' Integrating the quote in the commentary to compare your idea with the evidence was a smart choice. It made the essay flow well.
