First body paragraph can be broken into 2 seperate body paragrahs and ideas. Break up each rehtorical strategy into a NEW paragraph. Ideas started to run together and became confusing.

The amount and accuracy of the textual references used in your essay is very sufficient. However, there is always room for improvement, and to really solidify your own essay, extra examples of each of the rhetorical strategies as well as the inclusion of a few more devices could be added.

The author provides adequate textual evidence, But, because the essay is sporatic, the evidence, even though it contributes to an understanding of Louv's purpose, doesn't tie well amongst itself. It's jumpy, a piece of evidence quickly cut to the next with some degree of analysis but no subcategory of purpose. The evidence would be stronger if, within each paragraph, it was grouped under a rhetorical device or strategy in order to streamline the lack of organization this essay entails.

You did good in finding rhetorical devices, but you really didn't explain how he used them very well. In the first body, you stated the device, but didn't use any textual evidence to support that. You need to go more in depth on explaining why and how he used the devices to get to his purpose.  In the second one, you did give evidence to support your thesis and rhetorical device, but, again, you could have gone more in depth. Maybe you could have added you're own personal experience or talked more about the story he told.  In the third, you mentioned that Richard told stories, so go in depth and explain the stories and why he told them. What was his purpose in doing that? And then tie it back to the thesis.
Used the authors name correctly ,but should mention the book title as well.

The end of the thesis is excellent. It is exactly how Mrs. Lepore has taught us to write the thesis, but the beginning is lacking. Your supporting ideas aren't very strong ideas which causes you to be very repetitive throughout your essay.
Your essay was very easy to read and follow. It flows very well.
Each quote is explained thoroughly and connected back to the essay''s thesis statement.
The author provided explanations to support their analysis of each one fo Louv's rhetorical strategies used in the passage.

The organization of the essay flows well and the author uses good transitions like ''in conclusion'' and ''also'' to join each paragraph. However, the essay could be greatly enhance by the seperation of the paragraphs about appeals to logos and ethos into seperate paragraphs.

The author chooses to focus primarily on the modes portrayed in Louv's piece. While the author manages to analyze Louv's argument through these strategies, they did not capture the most important devices such as Louv's nostalgia and appeal to a cause. The author connects their points to Louv's argument, but they didn't catch enough of what was essential to his piece.

All of the quotes that you used seemed to support your choices. The only ones that seemed misinterpreted were the hypothetical examples. I think that those examples could tie into pathos effortless rather than fitting them into a ccatagory they aren't associated with.
The thesis is very good. It's understandable and uses your own thoughts to come up with it.

Analysis was concise and effective.  I would like to see a little more analysis, especially in the third paragraph, which feels a little rushed.  The conclusion almost was a fake out 4th paragraph, but it actually wrapped up the piece nicely. I would like to see an example of what the plan for change exactly was.

The rhetorical strategies that you picked were specific and were analyzed pretty well. I like how you connected all your devices to a specific quote in the speech, how they conveyed her overall message, and how they affected her audience. Very effective and grabbed my attention.
Strong word choice and very few grammatical errors.
The author provides a great amount of quotes, and interweaves them accordingly to allow the reader to understand fully what the purpose of the essay is. Vocabulary could use work but great job.

Great incorporation of textual evidence into essay--it flows well and is not a ''naked quote.'' You provide the context for the quote in the same sentence without it being awkward. Continue to do this!

The writer explains the textual evidence in her analysis thoroughly.  Her explanation of the textual evidence allowed me to inderstand the author's language on a new level.  Their evidence and explanation highly increased the strength of their essay and overall claim.
I loved your thesis. It wasn't too confusing or too simple.

There is one sentence I highlighted but I'm not sure went through. The sentence is, ''When he speaks of technology, he switches to a more depressing mood, which seems to show that technology is sending into a never-ending spiral downwards into an uncaring feeling toward technology. '' This sentence is the worst sentence in the entire essay, as it makes no sense and is very unclear to the reader. Revise this for future reference.
Your explantaions were a little bit confusing as you didn't have that much information to support your ideas.

Good organization, each rhetorical device from the thesis has its own body paragraph. The conclusion is a little abrupt, ''In 1909, Kelley helped create the NAACP,'' but I understand with the time constraint.
Clear language and grammar. The choice of speech seemed a little too formal but it was consistant.

The argument was not very present and again was more of a restatement. Develop your interpratation of the position and start your argument from there. Just saying nature and humanity is seperating is not enough.
Minor grammatical and spelling errors, such as wrong form of ''its'' at one point. Could flow better.

Yes, the author included a clear and somewhat specific thesis in the introduction. It is effective and clear, although, as aforementioned, specificity could be enhanced, though perhaps at the price of more words.

In some cases, there were area where grammar could be improved including the intriductin where sentence structure could have been more varied ( Louv....   . Louv......     .) The vocab was at a sufficent level but there were no words that just said wow. In some places, certain stronger words, could have served to develop the essay better like saying creating a sense of astonishment and replacing people with society to create a more polished work.
Well structured. Unfocused or distracting on occasion (like in the conclusion), but it is well organized.

The anecdote of Louv's friend's car purchase does not relate to your stance that there is a division betwen people and nature. It analyzes car sales, not the division. In the last sentence, you mention how the anecdote ''adds a bitter undertone to the essay '' (paragraph 2). This could be expanded on more. How does that bitterness reveal Louv's purpose and intent? Does it say anything about how Louv views the division? Your explanation of how the rhetorical questions and imagery convey a sense of nostalgia are well-put. What does the nostalgia say about Louv's purpose? You make very good points. Try to bring them around a full circle and elaborate how they reate to Louv's argument.
As stated, your argument was not in compliance with what Louv spoke of. There are some portions that I think coincide with Louv's statement, but not choosing a side also hurts your argument.
The author does not really have an introduction but they do have a body and conclusion.

Body paragraph two is insufficient in length, it is not long enough to establish a full argument. Also you use a lot of fragments that just aren't sentences. It seems like maybe you didn't reread this because there are a lot of grammatical errors that could be easily fixed. The paragraph doesn't prove your thesis and you insert a lot of unnessecary information in this short paragraph, like including the word what was italicized to ''display the shock of his grandchildren when they find out what it was like without technology back then.'' This doesn't focus on contrast and doesn't really add anything to your essay. I was dissapointed to see only two body paragraphs
You use good language and grammar.
Many direct quotes that support the argument. However, better integration of quotes is needed. Several quotes are not integrated at all, which severely dtracts from the essay.

The evidence for pathos could have been more specific. I understand that you might have not wanted to quote the text if it was too long, but really consider giving more context and later, more analysis.

The author attempts at explaining, describing that ''By choosing to include this piece of information it juxtaposes against the argument that Louv makes for the rest of the article'' and that '' it only serves to further his argument that nature is being destroyed''. However, the author seems to believe that the points are obvious and can be easily seen without clear direction. Thus, the discussion is somewhat ''jumpy'' from one point to another.
You explain his rhetorical strategies okay but at times it seems to get off track and confusing. Youalso only talk about two strategies
Thesis just seemed like a simple and blunt list. It wasn't detailed or ''spiced-up'' enough.
The author adequetly organized their essay. They included a specific thesis, support for their thesis, and a conclusion to summarize their thoughts.
You also want to mention what these rhetorical devices do for her speech. Is her audience affected or...? Specificity is key!

I feel that this is what you did best on. The language was decently thought through and conistent, as well as a little wordy. Try taking unnessary adjectives out of your essay, I think that would make it a lot better. But I do appreciate the diversity!

In general, your essay was organized well and was easy to read. However, I think there are a few things you can improve on. One thing that I noticed is that your conclusion paragraph is really short. That happens a lot with these kinds of essays, so it's important to manage your time well and know when it is time to move on to the next paragraph. Other than that, your essay is structured well.
Your second body paragraph has a gem! ''Kelley not only wanted her audience to sympathize but to empathize for these children.'' Wow. 10/10. A+.
Not all evidence is logical(refer to extended metaphor review)
The thesis was a little to vague. Maybe should use different choice of words in the thesis.
Focus on the prompt.  Analyze rhetorical devices the author uses.  Try not to add personal stories.
I thought that your evidence for your emotioanl appeal paragraph and your rhetorical questioning paragraph were very supportive and accuratley refelcted your assertions!

'It all started with the first wheel and now includes cars with “backseat television monitors”. AWK The language is fair good. I saw few grammer mistakes but you could always use stronger verbs. Take out all uses and replace them with better verbs.

Your orginization was good. It followed the pattern that you layed out in the begining of the essay. The thing you need to do is to look at your into and concluding paragraphs and look at the organization of them. They are a litle jumbled and could be more crisp and to the point. I feel like they include unnecessary information the kind of just beats around the bush.
The seperation argueement is easily seen.
The organization of the essay was good. Although, some diction made some sentences awkward, the whole gist of the essay and the author's points were not passed over.
Well organized. Paragraphs are based on what is stated in the thesis. Not choppy.

Your thesis states the rhetorical appeals in an order reverse of how you presented them in your following paragraphs. This is a common issue with many of us, but outlining your paper in the order in which you will present the information before creating your final thesis can help. If you list ideas in the outline but are more sure of your later ideas, switch the order before finalizing your thesis.

There is a fragment in the introduction (''Although, there is a question of whether or not we are becoming too dependent on technology.'') that is caused by the misuse of ''although'' and can be fixed by replacing it with ''however''. There are minor errors throughout the essay (''on being'', ''...a screen. many...'') and the language is not very sophisticated (''he thinks...'', ''he is saying...''). The vocabulary is adequate, but there should not be first person in a formal essay. Don't use vague language (''this'', etc), and the connotations of ''baffled'' may not be the most accurate for Louv's feelings.

I like the way your essay is organized. One tip, you start off the essay very generically. Instead of starting with ''In the ...'' try something like, ''In today's world technology is advancing faster than ever. This leads to (Positives). However...'' then start the way you did. This is nice, because I guarentee the person grading your paper has read countless essays with ''In the novel...'', ''In the book...'', etc. When they see an essay with an interesting start, they'll be hooked on the paper immediately.

Your use of language got the reader confused in some areas and didn't help you get your point across at times.  The vocabulary isnt the strongest but doesnt hurt the essay too.  You do a good job in not overusing certain verbs a lot in the essay.  Grammar doesnt seem to have very many errors.
The author supported their anaylsis well but could've used more examples from the text.

Nice vocab - using words like ''apathetic'' and ''denounce'' strengthened your thesis and overall argument. You also varied your wording throughout the essay, which is helpful and makes it easier to read
You could also analyze the evidence you provide with more depth into HOW and WHY Louv uses these devices, instead of leaving it at WHAT the quotes do for Louv's purpose.

In paragraph 4, the reference to the Conestoga wagon is not a reference to pathos. You interpreted Louv's description different than it was intended to. The reference was meant to be shown as how much technology has changed and how different life was with little technology. The reference to the Conestoga wagon was more of an anecdote than a reference to pathos.
Bad organizaton, because of a scattered way of thinking, needed more structure.

Your analysis of the evidence is pretty solid. Except you don't offer much anaylsis on the first quote of the first paragraph about ''two million children...win bread''. You could possibly talk about how children should not be expected to provide for their families at such a young age and how shocking the sheer number of working children has increased (2mil is alot).

-Try using other verbs besides ''use.'' Your writing is at such a high level that little things such as diversifying your word choice are the only ways to improve your essays. -combination is a singular noun, so its verb ought to be singular as well (are should be is) ''The combination of “little girls” and “deafening noise” are especially effective...''

You used a lot of incorrect words and your sentences were poorly structured. The grammer was not very good either and a lot of your sentences didn't make any sense. If you want the reader to understand what you're trying to say in your explanation and evidence, you have to make sure the language you use to explain your explanation and evidence makes sense.

In the first paragraph, the author uses an example from Kelley's sppech and then takes two or three sentences to elaborate the cited words' impact before moving onto the text example associated with that device. It is an efficient way to write.   The other body paragraphs (two additional ones I believe) explain Kelley's realtionship with the association well and essentially followed the plan that the thesis set up. There was no conetextual evidence in these, however.

A lot of the textual evidence is incorporated in a sentence that illustrates your analysis and thus offers incontrovertible assertions. You also incorporate further explanations for some of your quotes.
Also why is the list of recollections that Louv makes a ''personal connection'' with his audience? What effect do they have?
There is little to no evidence. If I had not read the paper I would not have know that some of your examples were in the paper. Try quoting from the source instead of just saying he said something.

You suffciently explained your evidence, but I think you could analyze it deeper. Instead of just using one sentence to explain each supporting factor, go further in depth and think about why it makes the reader feel that way. Also, it's not okay that you used a question to explain your evidence.
the author organised the essay very well and made it easy to read.

He/ she does not really explain the connection to Louv's argument well. She could fix this in all of her body paragraphs, but she should pay close attention to the 2nd body paragraph because she lacks any analysis whatsoever.

The author analyzed the rhetorical strategies of the piece rather vaguely.  They did not go into much detail about it and I feel that they could have analyzed more deeply about the strategies being used.
The evidence for your claims were absolutely perfect. However, you can totally challenge yourself by using claims that are more hidden and possibly more intriguing than the basic.
Your explanation for her use of logos is accurate, but elaborating on it would make it better.

Here's what I see as evidence for a claim you make in the 2nd paragraph:  ''This statement is used in the  passage to illustrate how humans aren’t realizing how much nature does for us already, it gives us  oxygen to breathe and yet people are still “[stamping their messages into the wet sand,” and also “using  nature as an ad space.”  To me this more paraphrase than analysis.
positive- use of many strong emamples from the text and quotes to prove point stongly.
Maybe try to break it down into a few sentences. It was a run on. I understand wiht the time crunch though.

In your thesis, you tell which strategies you will explain but it is at the end of your sentence. I think to enhance your thesis, you should put the three strategies you will be explaining towards the front of the sentence. This will also make your thesis better.

Organization is appropriate. With your open thesis, it is possible to get off track. However, you mainly stuck to the prompt, although the ideas of child labor and woman suffrage didn't seem to flow methodically in the essay. Remember, Kelley took advantage of the audience's sympathy of children to then sneak in her other conention about suffrage. Also, be more specific as you near the ends of your body paragraphs by including more in depth analysis. For the final paragraph, delete ''her ability to emotionally provoke her audience enables her...''  and insert more overarching material, final analysis and then a suitable closing sentence.

Your thesis is a bit formulaic, especially if you use the word ''Through,'' however I can see why you may have resorted to the ''formula thesis'' because it does its job AND its a time saver.  So at the end of the essay if you have time you should try to re work it so it doesnt seem so ''bare bones''

Thank you so much for this great opening, the last essay I read was pretty bad. The only concern I have is that you may have too many rhetorical strategies in the thesis, but I like your intro paragraph a lot. You may just want to reread it for word choice. Also, while the first sentence is interesting, it seems like a generic sentence that you could use for any and all rhetorical analysis prompts we use; it seems too formulaic and you may want to consider replacing it.
you have 3 pieces of evidence but i think they could have been a little more developed instaed of listed.

The author provides moments of great insight when explaining the evidence (e.g. ''The author includes the audience through the word “we” in order to make the essay more inclusive and capturing their attention, so they also begin to reminisce about their past explorations'' and ''“The dancing rain” (69) emphasizes the joy and positive connotation that rain can have even when considered poor weather''. ). However, there are places where the essay could be made stronger if additional commentary was provided (e.g.''The author calls out on the hypocritical parents who say they hate TV, but then thrust the TV on them. He retaliates on them, demanding them to realize what technology has done to the newer generation.'') Here more specificity would have made he essay stronger, such as saying the ''increasing obssesion and dependence on technology has led to a disconnect with nature''.
the essay is pretty well organized and uses 1 rhetoriical device per paragraph and keeps it very simple.
Deep depth of rhetorical strategies used.
You should refrain from using personal analogies, dont correct other people's grammar, and you should analyze the prompt with clear ideas.

You referred to the text quite a bit but I noticed that you didn't pull out any direct quotes. I would suggest going back through and finding the points you're making and pulling out a direct quote that would help enhance your analysis for the reader. Maybe start in paragraph three when you're talking about rhetorical questions and pull out one from line 43-45 in Louv's essay.

An Ad Hominum argument is one which is attacking a specific individual, which doesn't actually appear in the speech.  However, I like your idea of analyzing the structure of the essay.  Perhaps you can talk about parralellism or some other structural element.
These are soli rhetorical devices yyou use, you should consider talking about one more strategy Kelley uses to stregthen your arguement.

This essay is set-up exactly how the thesis outlines it to be set up. There are clear transitions between the paragraphs which also benefit the level of writing ability. I would suggest adding a little bit more to the conclusion, as it is only one sentence and does not completely fulfill its job. Overall, the piece is very well organized with connections back to the thesis in every paragraph.

The language was not as sophisticated as it could have been. The vocabulary was a bit simplistic and not as elaborate as it should have been. There are a few moments where great vocabulary is used, but that should be happnening throughout the entire paper.

The evidence is more to explain your statement but you do not explain why the eplanation makes sense. Document your expanations and give a reason for why you did it. Act as if you have to explain everything
Also, improve your writing by using more effective words. Replace words like ''annoyed'' and ''feel bad'' with stronger adjectives like ''agitated'' and ''broiling,'' or ''contrite'' and ''ashamed.''
Good explaination of the usage of ethos and logos.
Very well-written essay overall. You have a clear command of language, but at time it seemed you could have given more in-depth vocabulary or syntax. Easy to read, and simple and concise.

The author should try to add a more enticing first sentence! . The author's use of the word ''campaign'' is misleading because it makes the reader think that Kelley is running for office or for a position when she is actually trying to promote child labor reform and start a movement. What is Kelley's campaign? The author should also consider adding a little more explanation when he or she says ''Kelley conveys her points with a separation of the children and the adults and emotional appeal.'' The author should change 'separation of children and adults' to emphasizing the extremities of child labor reform because Kelley is contrasting the comfortable lives of the women in the audience to the harsh working conditions of these poor people, specifically the children. If Kelley separates the children and the adults, how is she separating them? Which adults?
There was some good language use in the first paragraph, but after that it was bland.

There are some obvious points the aithor is trying to make within the essay about Louv's views, however, they are not properly detailed. For instance, ''The last sentence of the first paragraph is where it best explains Louv's discord agaisnt the multi-national buisnesses who want to defile nature'' would be a good sentence to allude to and an excellent point to make if it was ellaborated on, however this sentence is all that is shown. Also, the focus of the essay should be leaned more toward Louv's views than the views of others, such as the car dealer, and the more detailed part of the argument should not be in the conclusion where it is now.

Decent organization. You may want to add topic sentences and conclusion sentence at the beginning and end of your body paragraphs to make your essay more coherent. This will also help your essay flow better.
One suggestion is to further explain the last quote “for the sake…” so the reader understands how it supports your thesis.

The thesis clearly explains the rhetorical devices and the purpose/theme of the rest of essay being that since mankind is becoming more involved with material wealth it has caused a separation from nature.

The essay is well-organized. It has all the necessary parts including the introduction, body paragraphs, and conclusion. The thesis was identified in the introduction and all the rhetorical strategies were addressed in the order they were stated in the thesis. I really liked that at the end of every body paragraph the author connected it to the next one by saying ''further more'' or ''in addition''. This organization made the essay flow better and all the ideas has a logical connections.

The separation between nature and people is well described but some of the claims are repeated. Each body paragraph has some reference to the separation which makes your claim connected to the thesis at all times. The repetiton of the same argument like ''call to action'' reduces the impact of the your argument. The descriptions of the argument are accurate. Try to add more ideas and references from the text.
The other two body paragraph were well developed.
Your essay was very well organized. I'm especially fond of the way you chose to bridge each body paragraph from the other; your use of chronology makes the essay very easy to comprehend.

The analysis is underdeveloped and sort of focuses on a different perspective of the connections between people and nature by talking about the unison that it should be in, instead of addressing the evidence of the rhetorical strategies to prove the seperation between mankind and mother nature. He/she understands the rhetorical strategies utilized but the analysis is not as developed as it could be, the prompt throughout the analysis also becomes lost in the rambling of a different subject which loses the connection between the analysis and the thesis.

Content of the paragraphs are easy to follow and flow smoothly.  However, it could use a little more structure within.  Be sure to not necessarily use evidence when trying to explain another piece of evidence.  It's like inception: evidence within evidence within evidence.

The author provides direct quotes in every body paragraph to support his/her analysis of Louv's rhetorical strategies. The author does a good job of using the quotes to address Louv's viewpoints on his argument.
There is literally one quote in the whole essay. They talk a lot about the author's ''story'' that Louv told about his friend going to buy a car.

- Because you don't have textual evidence for each rhetorical device--you dont have substantial analysis for the rhetorical devices. You could go more into depth. You only provide one sentence for polysyntedon and nothing for rhetorical devices. Explain how these devices make the audience react and what they evoke.
Could work on grammar (spelling anaphora+ replacing'' development of ethos with '' Using devices A+B+C to support his arguement driven by ethos)

The essay had strong organization that followed the order outlined in the intro. The assertion that Louv points out the disadvantages of making nature obsolete is not really connected with the rest of the essay, as though many aspects of the benefits of nature or mentioned, it remains unclear exactly why making nature obsolete has disadvantages.

There are quite a few spellig errors in the essay that I happened to notice. On top of the ones I said earlier, you also misspelled towards in the topic sentence of body paragraph 3. Besides a few minor things though, I though you did a sufficient job in this category. It was easy to understand, but I recommend trying to use a few really advanced words because it sounds cool and complilcated, so when people read it they think it is an advanced essay right off the bat.

The author explains Louv's argument two sentences before the thesis statement. This allows the author to describe how Louv's argument of the seperation of people and nature is formed through the rhetorical strategies they listed in their thesis sentence. The explanation is very clear and the thesis gives the author the chance to continue the idea of Louv's argument throughout the piece.

You explain the textual evidence well, describing how the quotation creates meaning and how, but there should be a transition or some commentary because without it, it makes the paragraphs seem abrupt and hurried.  The textual evidence helps support the overall message and guides the reader to exactly where you developed your thoughts
The author of this piece shows their extensive understanding of vocabulary and grammar.  These aspects are put together very well to create a very sophisticated and well written essay.
As with your spare explanations, the support for you explanations is not very thorough either. Try referring more to the text.

The author analyzed Louv's examples, ironies, and comparisons to explain a difference in younger and older generations and how the development of technology has made the younger generations more reliant on them and ignorant of natural surroundings. Each of the author's chosen rhetorical strategies address this generation difference and its effect on the separation of people and nature.
You did a decent job. You could have gone into more detail. Also you could have made a better argument and have said if technology was good or bad for people.

The imagery of two million young children working daily, could have fueled the furious crowd to start a revolt- this piece of evidence you used is very strong because it creates a vivid statistic while building your own ethos

You do a great job of explaining the evidence you use to support your claims.  The second paragraph's evidence is especially well done because you examined most of the evidence before producing the quote as an example.  This works well but for variation in your writing try opening the paragraph with a quote and using the rest of the paragraph to examine and explain the quote.  You could also try integrating one of your quotes into an original sentence.

The author's organization is clear and focused. His or her paragraphs frequently relate back to his or her thesis. Each piece of commentary is clearly connected to some sort of reference, whether it is implicitly stated or explicitly stated. The essay is easy to follow, and the ideas do not jump around.

You explain your evidence in the first body paragraph very well. In the second body paragraph, you just quote a sentence without directly addressing it. I know you're trying to prove that Kelley is appealing to pathos and trying to get the audience to sympathize, and that the quote you use is good for that, just explain the point you're trying to make in reference to the quote.

The author was able to organize his or her essay logically, providing a sufficient thesis statement and body paragraphs addressing the thesis.  However some of the explanations don't connect back to the thesis.

The 2nd paragraph does not talk about Louv's about the separation between people and nature. Connecting the point that advertisers take advantage of nature for financial success to Louv's argument would strengthen the essay. This could be done by asserting that mankind does not appreciate nature for its beauty or complexity, but instead as a tool, which illustrates mankind's separation from nature as they see nature as a means of success and not a powerful force to be reckoned with.

The author needed to include more analysis. While analyzing the contrast in the excerpt, the onlly analysis he provides is ''This contrast establishes the extent to which parents are willing to go to achieve “backseat peace” while also presenting the material children are exposed to in the modern world, which is of a larger scope in maturity than the material of previous generations.'' The author should have included more analysis than one simple sentence. Connecting the analysis to the thesis and then to the following paragraph would have been better within this essay.
Your points made sense yet they lacked whenever you used so many quotations.  Stay away from quotations and try paraphrasing.

The author rarely analyzed the quotes they provided. They simply stated them and then restated them in a different word arrangement. They didnt realy provide insight to the quotes but rather summarized. The author says Louv employed personification and cliches yet they fail to provide evidence for those claims. The quotes provided are just thrown all into one paragraph and are rarely explained and analyzed. They dont really connect back to the thesis and ''the seperation of people and nature.''
The author is able to include direct quotes and evidence on multiple occasions, is also able to avoid any ''naked'' quotes.
The authors's grammar and vocabulary was standard.

Two body paragraphs interconnect very well and provide a better effect than three separate examples. Conclusion is succinct but adequate. The conclusion could include a piece to tie together her rhetorical devices before going on to consider the implications of her speech.
he supported the the evidence but did not give enough information

In your thesis statement you say that Louv's argument is that nature is important to today's youth, but earlier in the introduction you say, ''the writer argues that humans should be more involved with nature.'' You should make it more clear if Louv's argument pertains to all humans or only children. You could either change your beginning sentence to include only children or change the thesis to all people.
in an essay like this one you need to provide a rhetorical strategies that state wether or not the author used these. In your essay you explained these very well in a well developed paragraph.

You answered the question and it flows smoothly good job! The only thing I would maybe change to make it flow easier would be to switch the two sentences, ''It all started with...'' and ''People continue to connect...''.
positive- its very strong and you left room to include lots of ideas. well done

Your second argument that people's obligations to their culture is explained by demonstrating how by not being restricted by cultural obligations allow people to truly reveal their identity. Your argument is clearly defined in the thesis and supported by the body paragraphs by Bell and in “Half the Sky: Turning Oppression into Opportunity for Women Worldwide”. However, this piece of evidence does not demonstrate how ethnicity inhibits identity so in your thesis you should mention enthnicity and gender.

There is a missing transition. In the second paragraph you start with ''Louv uses repetition throughout his argument, specifically in lines 63-73.'' There should be some sort of transition used to start the first body paragraph.

You directly quoted some parts of the passage. That was good. Also, when you did directly quote it, you incoorporated it so it flowed with what you were saying. It wasnt reandomly or awkwardly placed.
Better spacing out your time for each of you point would have helped to get 1 or 2 more points.
The thesis included all the necessities.

In Paragraph 2, instead of saying ''the most prominent,'' try ''one of the most prominent'' since reader may disagree; for the last sentence try explaining how Kelley relates ''the tedious, reptitive nature of factory work'' to ''the parallel structure in her piece.
Great use of quotational evidence. Strong examples in each paragraph; just try not to overuse evidence so it won't drain out your argument.

You follow a basic structure that is both easy for the reader to follow and effective in crafting an argument. I enjoy how your body paragraphs dont lead with a first sentence that directly says what you plan on talking about. Instead you let the reader see you develop your ideas and figure out what you will discuss, which is more advanced than explicitly stating your claim for the paragraph.

The evidence is partially explained if at all, and it is never connected to the thesis. I suggest taking the evidence and going a bit deeper into what it means, then explaining how Louv uses that to support his argument.

My peer's thesis statment is in two sentences and is very clear.  In my peer's thesis, he/she discusses that they will talk about Louv's argument, but they do not clearly define what Louv's argument is (what is the realtionship? how should it be changed?)  Another thing that my peer did well on was to discuss what rhetorical devices that further Louv's argument.

The rhetorical strategies the author uses in their essay are not very strong ones . The author does not include diction at all when explaining strategies and that is a magor componenet of louvs argument
Your thesis is well written and flows nicely. The reader can easily tell what your paper is about and where you will be going. Good job! :)
author obviously understood 2 of the rhetorical devices used. the only problem is that there's only about 3.25 paragraphs, so he/she couldn't get them all explained
Could use more direct quotes
The thesis is strong and clear. Clearly has thought put into it and evidence to back up what's stated.

The thesis of this paper is not clear. The peice was written in arguminative format instead of a rhetorical anlaysis.  It is clear that this student feels that parents are curropting thier children in a negative way by allowing them too much access to tv and violent video games. However, the exact thesis is not clear and its not written in a single cohecisve sentence.
Your essay is well organized, you stated your thesis in the way you wrote your essay which made it easy to follow along.

Explaining the textual evidence is pretty good considering how little there is.  You draw conclusions about how car rides for children have changes which is getting on the right path but you fail to take the next step to talk about how that relates to nature.  If your evidence was stronger it would make your dialgoue look even better and you would draw stronger conclusions to more around what Louv's real purpose is.

The evidence is explained well. The rhetorical stratgey is clearly stated and then the author explains the evidence before connecting the two. However, as there was no thesis, there was nothing to connect them to.

While there were a few grammar errors, (with use of ; for example the first sentence, you should use two full sentences when using a ; ) their were many cases of good use of vocabulary, for example, *the taxing work children are experiencing...unholy amount, a sure-fire way to gain...delicacy thrown to the wind...* which I think helped your argument. There were some cases though where I thought that a better word would fit.. for example ''smartly structures'' you could maybe use she  *strategically structures*

Closed thesis, list-like format. For the most part it worked, but watch out to make sure you don't introduce new ideas as you write without including them in your intro. Appealing to patriotism is an example of this problem.

The author does a good job at explaining how imagery contributes to Louv's argument and the beauty of nature. In the second body paragraph, it is slightly unclear as to how the rhetorical questions contribute to Louv's argument that mankind and nature are being divided. But there is commentary as to what the rhetorical questions are saying. The third paragraph analyzes the anaphra ''we'' well.

There are a few lapses in grammar. For example, in your sentence ''By connecting to his audience emotionally, Louv involves them with the issue, makes them recognize...'' (paragraph 4) the ''them'' should be ''it'', because an audience is singular. In paragraph 5, there are shifts in tense, from present (''Louv worries'') to past (''he has appealed''). You can easily replace ''he has appealed'' to simply ''appeals''. On the whole, these mistakes are trivial and do not obstruct understanding the essay. At times, your prose becomes colloquial or contrasts sharply with your overall sophisticated diction. For example, ''To hammer in his final point...'' (paragraph 4) sounds clunky and informal. In paragraph 2, you do not need to define what an anecdote is.

If you read your thesis closely again, you will see that there is a minor error in flow/parallelism.  ''posing'' could change to ''poses''.  Doesn't take anything away from its strength and meaning though.
